dataset.title: Methane fluxes from an Alaskan rich fen (APEX)

address.deliveryPoint: Dept. Plant Biology, Michigan State University

abstract.para: Methane fluxes were collected at APEX rich fen using the static chamber method during the summer of 2005 and summer 2006. The field site uses a full-factorial water table (flooded or raised, lowered or drained, and control plots, as well as a moisture gradient) by warming manipulation experiment (warmed, unwarmed) which are reflected in the plot column and the warming column, respectively.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: APEX rich fen located in the Bonanza Creek Long-term ecological research center outside of Fairbanks, Alaska, USA

address.deliveryPoint: Dept. Plant Biology, Michigan State University

section.title: methane flux using static chamber method
section.para: Methane samples were collected from clear static chambers (0.6 m x 0.6 m x 0.6 m) placed on collars that are permanently embedded in the peat. Collars were sealed using foam tape. Gas samples were collected over a period of 30 - 40 minutes and analyzed for methane concentrations using a GC equipped with an FID detector.

description.para: Data were collected from 18 collars located within the water table by warming treatments at APEX as described above. Moisture gradient collars range from a black spruce site (Gradient 1), a site dominated by willow-birch (Gradient 2), a tussock site (Gradient 3, located on a tussock), and a site dominated by equisetum and carex (Gradient 4). Data coverage at all sites from 6/16/2005 - 8/22/2005, and from 6/19/2006 - 9/10/2006.

samplingDescription.para: Water table treatments were randomly assigned to each plot. Permanent gas measurement collars were established within these plots and randomly assigned to a warming treatment.
